newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end down, spots up.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end down, spots up.

text.p: Contracts on the treasury bill repurchase market in Shanghai closed mostly down in slow trading on Tuesday mainly due to ample fund supply on the market on a slowdown in new domestic A share issues, traders said.
The annual rate for the most actively traded three-day contract plunged to 5.8 percent from 10.1 percent on Monday.
Total turnover of the six-contract market fell to 3.2 million lots from 5.5 million lots.
One lot is 1,000 yuan face value of treasury bills.
Traders said a lack of new share issues from Monday to Wednesday on the domestic A share markets saw money supply far exceed demand on the repo market.
The repo rates are likely to rebound on Wednesday due to a number of new A share issues on the Shanghai stock exchange on Thursday and Friday, traders said.
Contracts on the T-bill spot market in Shanghai ended mostly up on Tuesday on a technical rebound supported by the contracts' high yields of more than 10 percent on average, traders said.
The most actively traded 10-year bond that matures in June 2006 rose to 121.39 yuan from 121.21 yuan.
Combined volume of the eight-contract market fell sharply to 827,984 lots from 1.4 million lots.
Traders said the high yields supported the contracts to stage a rebound despite a lack of liquidity on the spot market with active domestic share markets sucking money out.
Traders said they expected the spot contracts to move narrowly around the current level in the next few days.
